text:
Clapham’s approach tapped into the power of celebrating progress.  

A police officer pulled over a teenager one day.  

The teenager had saved a girl from being hit by a car.  

The officer gave him a Positive Ticket.  

He said, “You did a great thing today. You can make a difference.”  

The boy went home and put the Positive Ticket on his wall.  

After a few weeks, his foster mother asked about it.  

She wondered if he was going to cash it in.  

To her surprise, he said he never would.  

An adult had told him he could be somebody.  

That was worth more than free pizza or bowling.  

Multiply that type of positive interaction by forty thousand times a year.  

Do this for ten years to see the difference it makes.  

Each time a young person was recognized, it motivated them.  

Doing good became natural and effortless over time.  

When we want major change, we often think big.  

We think we need to lead with something grandiose.  

An executive I knew announced he would build his daughters a dollhouse.  

He abandoned the project because it felt too burdensome.  

There is appealing logic in thinking to start big.  

However, think of all the big initiatives that failed.  

They ended up amounting to nothing, just like the dollhouse.  

Research shows that the most effective motivation is progress.  

A small, concrete win creates momentum.  

It affirms our faith in further success.  

Frederick Herzberg wrote an article in 1968.  

It was titled “One More Time: How Do You Motivate Employees?”  

This article is one of the most popular of all time.  

Herzberg revealed that two primary motivators are achievement and recognition.  

Teresa Amabile and Steven Kramer gathered diary entries from many people.  

They covered thousands of workdays in their research.  

Based on these reflections, they concluded something important.  

Everyday progress, even a small win, can make a difference.  

They said, “Of all the things that can boost emotions, motivation, and perceptions,  

the single most important is making progress in meaningful work.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Celebrating small achievements fosters motivation and encourages continued positive behavior.
